title: [Large-Scale] PowerPoint-Based Effective Mathematics Teaching Method Awareness Improvement Program: Visual Elements and Data-Driven Design (Optimizing Formulas, Graphs, and Statistics)

context.prior_knowledge: Basic PowerPoint proficiency, secondary mathematics teaching experience (functions, calculus, statistics units), understanding of mathematical symbols (Σ/∫/Δ) and graph representation methods (coordinate systems/trend lines), comprehension of basic statistical concepts (mean/variance/standard deviation) and probability distributions
context.additional_context: A program for corporate math trainers to recognize PowerPoint pedagogy effectiveness and develop learner engagement strategies (e.g., visual proofs via graph-based limit explanations, data-driven design using correlation coefficient visualizations). Focuses on intuitive delivery tools for complex math concepts (differential equations, matrix operations, probability distributions), including visual representations of statistical analysis (regression/hypothesis testing) and proof processes (mathematical induction/limit proofs).

learning_goals: Learners can recognize the functional limitations of PowerPoint (e.g., excessive text copying, rapid pacing) and explain at least three learner-friendly slide design standards (e.g., visualizing formulas with LaTeX, optimizing graphs (axis labels/units), applying step-by-step animations (segmenting differentiation processes)).

When explaining math concepts (e.g., functions (continuity/differentiability), calculus (limits/integration), statistics (variance/regression analysis)), learners can design instructional materials using at least three visual elements (diagrams/charts, animations (visualizing proof processes), interactive elements (quizzes for probability problems)) and demonstrate the ability to achieve an average score of 4 or higher on a 5-point scale in peer reviews and expert evaluations.

Learners can collect PowerPoint usage data using a mixed-methods approach (100 quantitative surveys (5-point Likert scale) + 10 qualitative interviews (thematic analysis)), perform statistical analyses (mean/variance/correlation (Pearson’s r)), and develop an action plan including at least three improvement strategies (e.g., graph resolution enhancement, animation speed adjustment, formula font standardization) and a 3-month implementation timeline.

resources: Digital Survey Tool for Feedback Collection

difficulty: Moderate - Standard complexity with some constraints
